awd_titl_txt: EAGER: RUI: Elucidation of the AlCl4- and Al2Cl7- ions speciation, interactions and transport in electrolytes comprised of RTILs by Multi-Nuclear NMR techniques.
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical summary:
Societal energy needs demand the expansion of current electrical energy storage systems capabilities. Lithium ion batteries have dominated the markets due in part to lithium's high gravimetric and volumetric capacities and have advanced the development of products like electric vehicles and smartphones. However, they are expensive and more suitable for portable and small-scale applications due to lithium's limited long-term utility. Additionally, lithium ion batteries can be a fire hazard, a problem which has caused restrictions in their application and transportation. To ensure the advancement of society, improvements in electrical energy storage systems are needed and the development of aluminum ion batteries is one approach. Aluminum metal is attractive because of its low cost, low flammability and high charge storage capacity. Aluminum ion batteries are cheaper and safer than lithium ion ones, and they can be used for large-scale storage applications as needed by renewables like wind and solar. Their wide-scale application is, however, impeded by a number of factors, including a lack of enhanced electrolytes. This project, funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in NSF's Division of Materials Research, identifies electrolytes for aluminum ion batteries and investigates fundamental characteristics of ion transport that enable better performance in the future. The project incorporates educational programs for students of all levels and interests and involves students of all education levels in the research activities. The scientific broader impact of this project is to promote the advancement of science through enhancement of energy storage systems. This in turn advances the welfare of society through improvements in our living and environmental conditions.       

Technical summary: 
This project, funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in NSF's Division of Materials Research, elucidates the fundamental ion-ion interactions and their effects on ion dynamics and transport in aluminum ion battery electrolytes, addressing a lack of fundamental understanding of the aluminum ions' solvation, their interactions and transport.  Knowledge of all three is necessary for the optimization of the electrolytes and for advancing the development of aluminum ion batteries as alternative energy storage devices. Therefore, the PI and her group investigate the available free volume of all ions through measurements of multi-nuclear (protons, fluorine, aluminum and chlorine) magnetic resonance self-diffusion coefficients and spin-lattice relaxation times, both as a function of increasing hydrostatic pressure, and temperature.  Special focus will be on the aluminum nucleus. The procedure involves working both in the fringe-magnetic field to determine the pressure dependent self-diffusion coefficients, and in the homogeneous field to determine the temperature dependencies of the focused parameters. Through these measurements the researchers gain knowledge of the effect of aprotic organic solvents on the aluminum ion dynamics, and produce the first successful application of the aluminum high-pressure nuclear magnetic resonance technique. The electrolytes of interest are room temperature ionic liquids with imidazolium and pyrrolidinium cations, fluorosulfonamide and chlorine anions, containing the aluminum chloride compound combined with organic aprotic additives such as cyclopentane and benzene, with molar ratios of AlCl3/RTIL in the acidic range. This research opens the door for direct determination of the mass transport of other non-lithium ions in electrolytes and broadcasts the capabilities of the much-underutilized fringe-field high-pressure nuclear magnetic resonance technique.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The main objectives of this project were to investigate the ion-ion interactions and their effects on ions dynamics and transports in AlCl3 deep eutectic solvents by focusing on the microscopic dynamics. Towards these objectives we determined the various aluminum ion species in the prepared solvents and how their effect on ions’ transport is affected by various stimuli including AlCl3 concentration, hydrogen bond donor type, and temperature. 

Intellectual Merit: The determination of aluminum self-diffusion coefficients was realized through the Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Pulse Gradient Spin Echo technique. Currently, aluminum self-diffusion coefficients are not a standard accomplishment due to the associated difficulties of the nucleus, the samples and hardware. Because of this, the successful determination is a significant achievement for the research community. Work is still on-going to determine this parameter using the high-pressure NMR technique.    

 Broader Impact: The incorporation of active student learning throughout all aspects of the work both during the summers and the academic year satisfied the broader impact requirement. Especially noteworthy is the fact that all the data collected and published involved the participation of undergraduates (1F, 2M), graduate (1F, 1M) and four high school (4F and 4M) students. Two manuscripts were published1-2 with one in preparation3 resulted from this work. Presentation of the results were expected at eight conferences but due to COVID-19, only two resulted. Additionally, proposals based on these results are being prepared for submission to NSF and DOE.   

The results obtained from this project will help to advance the optimization the study of deep eutectic solvents and aluminum ion battery electrolytes. They will also provide researchers of non-lithium ion-based battery electrolytes a novel tool capable of exploring their electrolytes transport abilities. This can lead to low-cost advancements in applications ranging from portable electronics to grid storage and benefit the science community, the United States, and the world - especially densely populated developing areas.  

 

References: 

  1. Domenec Paterno, Emma Rock, Andrew Forbes, Nomon Mohammad, Sophia Suarez,* Aluminum ions speciation and transport in acidic deep eutectic AlCl3 amide electrolytes,  J. Molecular Liquids, 319, 2020, 114118. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2020.114118.
  2. D. Paterno, S. Suarez*, Charge Transport in Additive Modulated Aluminum Chloride Deep Eutectic Solvents (DES), ECS Transactions, 98, 401, 2020.
  3. D. Paterno, T. Pranto, S. Suarez, Working Title: The Effect of Carbonate Additive type on Aluminum Species Transport in AlCl3 Deep Eutectic Solvents. Manuscript in preparation for submission to J. Molecular Liquids in January 2022. 

 

Conference Presentations: (2 out of 8, 6 were cancelled due to COVID-19) 

  • (October, 2020). Sophia Suarez, Domenec Paterno, “Aluminum Ion Species Transport in Pure and Additive Modulated Deep Eutectic Solvents (DES) Electrolytes,” ECS PRIME, Hawaii, HI.  
  • Taiwo Odukoya, Joanna Zheng, Emma Rock, Nomon Mohammad, Andrew Forbes, Domenec Paterno, Sophia Suarez, “Aluminum Speciation and Transport in Acidic Deep Eutectic AlCl3 Amide Electrolytes”, American Museum of Natural History Consortium Research Symposium (AMNH), City College, 2019.  

 

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: Sophia Suarez
